segment.source: Create a Hello, world app (XAML)
segment.target: Create a Hello, world app (XAML)

segment.source: This tutorial teaches you how to use Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML) with C# to create a simple Hello, world app that targets the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) on Windows 10.
segment.target: This tutorial teaches you how to use Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML) with C# to create a simple Hello, world app that targets the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) on Windows 10.

segment.source: Create a "Hello, world" app (XAML)
segment.target: Create a "Hello, world" app (XAML)

segment.source: This tutorial teaches you how to use Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML) with C# to create a simple "Hello, world" app that targets the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) on Windows 10.
segment.target: This tutorial teaches you how to use Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML) with C# to create a simple "Hello, world" app that targets the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) on Windows 10.

segment.source: With a single project in Microsoft Visual Studio, you can build an app that runs on any Windows 10 device.
segment.target: With a single project in Microsoft Visual Studio, you can build an app that runs on any Windows 10 device.

segment.source: Here we focus on creating an app that runs equally well on desktop and mobile devices.
segment.target: Here we focus on creating an app that runs equally well on desktop and mobile devices.

segment.source: Important This tutorial is for use with Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 and Windows 10.
segment.target: Important This tutorial is for use with Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 and Windows 10.

segment.source: It won't work correctly with earlier versions.
segment.target: It won't work correctly with earlier versions.

segment.source: Here you'll learn how to:
segment.target: Here you'll learn how to:

segment.source: Create a new Visual Studio project that targets Windows 10 and the UWP.
segment.target: Create a new Visual Studio project that targets Windows 10 and the UWP.

segment.source: Add XAML content to your start page.
segment.target: Add XAML content to your start page.

segment.source: Handle touch, pen, and mouse input.
segment.target: Handle touch, pen, and mouse input.

segment.source: Run the project on the local desktop and on the phone emulator in Visual Studio.
segment.target: Run the project on the local desktop and on the phone emulator in Visual Studio.

segment.source: Adapt the UI to different screen sizes.
segment.target: Adapt the UI to different screen sizes.

segment.source: Before you start...
segment.target: Before you start...

segment.source: We're going to jump right into the steps you use to create a simple universal app.
segment.target: We're going to jump right into the steps you use to create a simple universal app.

segment.source: So we strongly recommend that you read and understand the overview information in What's new in Windows 10 and What's a Universal Windows app before you start this tutorial.
segment.target: So we strongly recommend that you read and understand the overview information in What's new in Windows 10 and What's a Universal Windows app before you start this tutorial.

segment.source: To complete this tutorial, you need Windows 10 and Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: To complete this tutorial, you need Windows 10 and Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: See Get set up for more info.
segment.target: See Get set up for more info.

segment.source: We assume you have a basic understanding of XAML and the concepts in the XAML overview.
segment.target: We assume you have a basic understanding of XAML and the concepts in the XAML overview.

segment.source: We also assume you're using the default window layout in Visual Studio.
segment.target: We also assume you're using the default window layout in Visual Studio.

segment.source: If you change the default layout, you can reset it in the Window menu by using the Reset Window Layout command.
segment.target: If you change the default layout, you can reset it in the Window menu by using the Reset Window Layout command.

segment.source: Step 1: Create a new project in Visual Studio
segment.target: Step 1: Create a new project in Visual Studio

segment.source: Launch Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: Launch Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: The Visual Studio 2015 Start page appears.
segment.target: The Visual Studio 2015 Start page appears.

segment.source: (From now on, we'll refer to Visual Studio 2015 simply as Visual Studio .)
segment.target: (From now on, we'll refer to Visual Studio 2015 simply as Visual Studio .)

segment.source: On the File menu, select NewProject.
segment.target: On the File menu, select NewProject.

segment.source: The New Project dialog appears.
segment.target: The New Project dialog appears.

segment.source: The left pane of the dialog lets you select the type of templates to display.
segment.target: The left pane of the dialog lets you select the type of templates to display.

segment.source: In the left pane, expand Installed > Templates > Visual C# > Windows, then pick the Universal template group.
segment.target: In the left pane, expand Installed > Templates > Visual C# > Windows, then pick the Universal template group.

segment.source: The dialog's center pane displays a list of project templates for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: The dialog's center pane displays a list of project templates for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: The New Project window
segment.target: The New Project window

segment.source: In the center pane, select the Blank App (Universal Windows) template.
segment.target: In the center pane, select the Blank App (Universal Windows) template.

segment.source: The Blank App template creates a minimal UWP app that compiles and runs, but contains no user-interface controls or data.
segment.target: The Blank App template creates a minimal UWP app that compiles and runs, but contains no user-interface controls or data.

segment.source: You add controls to the app over the course of this tutorial.
segment.target: You add controls to the app over the course of this tutorial.

segment.source: In the Name text box, type "HelloWorld".
segment.target: In the Name text box, type "HelloWorld".

segment.source: Click OK to create the project.
segment.target: Click OK to create the project.

segment.source: Visual Studio creates your project and displays it in the Solution Explorer.
segment.target: Visual Studio creates your project and displays it in the Solution Explorer.

segment.source: Visual Studio Solution Explorer for the HelloWorld project
segment.target: Visual Studio Solution Explorer for the HelloWorld project

segment.source: Although the Blank App is a minimal template, it still contains a lot of files:
segment.target: Although the Blank App is a minimal template, it still contains a lot of files:

segment.source: A manifest file (Package.appxmanifest) that describes your app (its name, description, tile, start page, and so on) and lists the files that your app contains.
segment.target: A manifest file (Package.appxmanifest) that describes your app (its name, description, tile, start page, and so on) and lists the files that your app contains.

segment.source: A set of logo images (Assets/Square150x150Logo.scale-200.png, Assets/Square44x44Logo.scale-200.png, and Assets/Wide310x150Logo.scale-200.png)to display in the start menu.
segment.target: A set of logo images (Assets/Square150x150Logo.scale-200.png, Assets/Square44x44Logo.scale-200.png, and Assets/Wide310x150Logo.scale-200.png)to display in the start menu.

segment.source: An image (Assets/StoreLogo.png) to represent your app in the Windows Store.
segment.target: An image (Assets/StoreLogo.png) to represent your app in the Windows Store.

segment.source: A splash screen (Assets/SplashScreen.scale-200.png) to display when your app starts.
segment.target: A splash screen (Assets/SplashScreen.scale-200.png) to display when your app starts.

segment.source: XAML and code files for the app (App.xaml and App.xaml.cs).
segment.target: XAML and code files for the app (App.xaml and App.xaml.cs).

segment.source: A start page (MainPage.xaml) and an accompanying code file (MainPage.xaml.cs) that run when your app starts.
segment.target: A start page (MainPage.xaml) and an accompanying code file (MainPage.xaml.cs) that run when your app starts.

segment.source: These files are essential to all UWP apps using C#.
segment.target: These files are essential to all UWP apps using C#.

segment.source: Every project that you create in Visual Studio contains them.
segment.target: Every project that you create in Visual Studio contains them.

segment.source: Step 2: Modify your start page
segment.target: Step 2: Modify your start page

segment.source: What's in the files?
segment.target: What's in the files?

segment.source: To view and edit a file in your project, double-click the file in the Solution Explorer.
segment.target: To view and edit a file in your project, double-click the file in the Solution Explorer.

segment.source: By default, you can expand a XAML file just like a folder to see its associated code file.
segment.target: By default, you can expand a XAML file just like a folder to see its associated code file.

segment.source: XAML files open in a split view that shows both the design surface and the XAML editor.
segment.target: XAML files open in a split view that shows both the design surface and the XAML editor.

segment.source: In this tutorial, you work with just a few of the files listed previously: App.xaml, MainPage.xaml, and MainPage.xaml.cs.
segment.target: In this tutorial, you work with just a few of the files listed previously: App.xaml, MainPage.xaml, and MainPage.xaml.cs.

segment.source: App.xaml and App.xaml.cs
segment.target: App.xaml and App.xaml.cs

segment.source: App.xaml is where you declare resources that are used across the app.
segment.target: App.xaml is where you declare resources that are used across the app.

segment.source: App.xaml.cs is the code-behind file for App.xaml.
segment.target: App.xaml.cs is the code-behind file for App.xaml.

segment.source: Code-behind is the code that is joined with the XAML page's partial class.
segment.target: Code-behind is the code that is joined with the XAML page's partial class.

segment.source: Together, the XAML and code-behind make a complete class.
segment.target: Together, the XAML and code-behind make a complete class.

segment.source: App.xaml.cs is the entry point for your app.
segment.target: App.xaml.cs is the entry point for your app.

segment.source: Like all code-behind pages, it contains a constructor that calls the method.
segment.target: Like all code-behind pages, it contains a constructor that calls the method.

segment.source: You don't write the method.
segment.target: You don't write the method.

segment.source: It's generated by Visual Studio, and its main purpose is to initialize the elements declared in the XAML file.
segment.target: It's generated by Visual Studio, and its main purpose is to initialize the elements declared in the XAML file.

segment.source: App.xaml.cs also contains methods to handle activation and suspension of the app.
segment.target: App.xaml.cs also contains methods to handle activation and suspension of the app.

segment.source: MainPage.xaml
segment.target: MainPage.xaml

segment.source: In MainPage.xaml you define the UI for your app.
segment.target: In MainPage.xaml you define the UI for your app.

segment.source: You can add elements directly using XAML markup, or you can use the design tools provided by Visual Studio.
segment.target: You can add elements directly using XAML markup, or you can use the design tools provided by Visual Studio.

segment.source: MainPage.xaml.cs is the code-behind page for MainPage.xaml.
segment.target: MainPage.xaml.cs is the code-behind page for MainPage.xaml.

segment.source: It's where you add your app logic and event handlers.
segment.target: It's where you add your app logic and event handlers.

segment.source: Together these two files define a new class called , which inherits from Page, in the namespace.
segment.target: Together these two files define a new class called , which inherits from Page, in the namespace.

segment.source: MainPage.xaml
segment.target: MainPage.xaml

segment.source: MainPage.xaml.cs
segment.target: MainPage.xaml.cs

segment.source: Modify the start page
segment.target: Modify the start page

segment.source: Now, let's add some content to the app.
segment.target: Now, let's add some content to the app.

segment.source: To modify the start page
segment.target: To modify the start page

segment.source: Double-click MainPage.xaml in Solution Explorer to open it.
segment.target: Double-click MainPage.xaml in Solution Explorer to open it.

segment.source: In the XAML editor, add the controls for the UI.
segment.target: In the XAML editor, add the controls for the UI.

segment.source: In the root Grid, add this XAML.
segment.target: In the root Grid, add this XAML.

segment.source: It contains a StackPanel with a title TextBlock, a TextBlock that asks the user's name, a TextBox element to accept the user's name, a Button, and another TextBlock to show a greeting.
segment.target: It contains a StackPanel with a title TextBlock, a TextBlock that asks the user's name, a TextBox element to accept the user's name, a Button, and another TextBlock to show a greeting.

segment.source: Some of these controls have names so that you can refer to them later in your code.
segment.target: Some of these controls have names so that you can refer to them later in your code.

segment.source: Step 3: Start the app
segment.target: Step 3: Start the app

segment.source: At this point, you've created a very simple app.
segment.target: At this point, you've created a very simple app.

segment.source: This is a good time to build, deploy, and launch your app and see what it looks like.
segment.target: This is a good time to build, deploy, and launch your app and see what it looks like.

segment.source: You can debug your app on the local machine, in a simulator or emulator, or on a remote device.
segment.target: You can debug your app on the local machine, in a simulator or emulator, or on a remote device.

segment.source: Here's the target device menu in Visual Studio.
segment.target: Here's the target device menu in Visual Studio.

segment.source: Drop-down list of device targets for debugging your app
segment.target: Drop-down list of device targets for debugging your app

segment.source: Start the app on a Desktop device
segment.target: Start the app on a Desktop device

segment.source: By default, the app runs on the local machine.
segment.target: By default, the app runs on the local machine.

segment.source: The target device menu provides several options for debugging your app on devices from the desktop device family.
segment.target: The target device menu provides several options for debugging your app on devices from the desktop device family.

segment.source: Simulator
segment.target: Simulator

segment.source: Local Machine
segment.target: Local Machine

segment.source: Remote Machine
segment.target: Remote Machine

segment.source: To start debugging on the local machine
segment.target: To start debugging on the local machine

segment.source: In the target device menu (Start debugging menu) on the Standard toolbar, make sure that Local Machine is selected.
segment.target: In the target device menu (Start debugging menu) on the Standard toolbar, make sure that Local Machine is selected.

segment.source: (It's the default selection.)
segment.target: (It's the default selection.)

segment.source: Click the Start Debugging button (Start debugging button) on the toolbar.
segment.target: Click the Start Debugging button (Start debugging button) on the toolbar.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: From the Debug menu, click Start Debugging.
segment.target: From the Debug menu, click Start Debugging.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: Press F5.
segment.target: Press F5.

segment.source: The app opens in a window, and a default splash screen appears first.
segment.target: The app opens in a window, and a default splash screen appears first.

segment.source: The splash screen is defined by an image (SplashScreen.png) and a background color (specified in your app's manifest file).
segment.target: The splash screen is defined by an image (SplashScreen.png) and a background color (specified in your app's manifest file).

segment.source: The splash screen disappears, and then your app appears.
segment.target: The splash screen disappears, and then your app appears.

segment.source: It looks like this.
segment.target: It looks like this.

segment.source: Initial app screen
segment.target: Initial app screen

segment.source: Press the Windows key to open the Start menu, then show all apps.
segment.target: Press the Windows key to open the Start menu, then show all apps.

segment.source: Notice that deploying the app locally adds its tile to the Start menu.
segment.target: Notice that deploying the app locally adds its tile to the Start menu.

segment.source: To run the app again (not in debugging mode), tap or click its tile in the Start menu.
segment.target: To run the app again (not in debugging mode), tap or click its tile in the Start menu.

segment.source: It doesn't do much—yet—but congratulations, you've built your first UWP app!
segment.target: It doesn't do much—yet—but congratulations, you've built your first UWP app!

segment.source: To stop debugging
segment.target: To stop debugging

segment.source: Click the Stop Debugging button (Stop debugging button) in the toolbar.
segment.target: Click the Stop Debugging button (Stop debugging button) in the toolbar.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: From the Debug menu, click Stop debugging.
segment.target: From the Debug menu, click Stop debugging.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: Close the app window.
segment.target: Close the app window.

segment.source: Start the app on a mobile device emulator
segment.target: Start the app on a mobile device emulator

segment.source: Your app runs on any Windows 10 device, so let’s see how it looks on a Windows Phone.
segment.target: Your app runs on any Windows 10 device, so let’s see how it looks on a Windows Phone.

segment.source: In addition to the options to debug on a desktop device, Visual Studio provides options for deploying and debugging your app on a physical mobile device connected to the computer, or on a mobile device emulator.
segment.target: In addition to the options to debug on a desktop device, Visual Studio provides options for deploying and debugging your app on a physical mobile device connected to the computer, or on a mobile device emulator.

segment.source: You can choose among emulators for devices with different memory and display configurations.
segment.target: You can choose among emulators for devices with different memory and display configurations.

segment.source: Device
segment.target: Device

segment.source: Emulator WVGA 4 inch 512MB
segment.target: Emulator WVGA 4 inch 512MB

segment.source: Emulator WVGA 4 inch 1GB
segment.target: Emulator WVGA 4 inch 1GB

segment.source: etc... (Various emulators in other configurations)
segment.target: etc... (Various emulators in other configurations)

segment.source: It's a good idea to test your app on a device with a small screen and limited memory, so use the Emulator 10.0.10240.0 WVGA 4 inch 512MB option.
segment.target: It's a good idea to test your app on a device with a small screen and limited memory, so use the Emulator 10.0.10240.0 WVGA 4 inch 512MB option.

segment.source: To start debugging on a mobile device emulator
segment.target: To start debugging on a mobile device emulator

segment.source: In the target device menu (Start debugging menu) on the Standard toolbar, pick Emulator 10.0.10240.0 WVGA 4 inch 512MB.
segment.target: In the target device menu (Start debugging menu) on the Standard toolbar, pick Emulator 10.0.10240.0 WVGA 4 inch 512MB.

segment.source: Click the Start Debugging button (Start debugging button) in the toolbar.
segment.target: Click the Start Debugging button (Start debugging button) in the toolbar.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: From the Debug menu, click Start Debugging.
segment.target: From the Debug menu, click Start Debugging.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: Press F5.
segment.target: Press F5.

segment.source: Visual Studio starts the selected emulator and then deploys and starts your app.
segment.target: Visual Studio starts the selected emulator and then deploys and starts your app.

segment.source: On the mobile device emulator, the app looks like this.
segment.target: On the mobile device emulator, the app looks like this.

segment.source: Initial app screen on mobile device
segment.target: Initial app screen on mobile device

segment.source: The first thing you'll notice is the button is pushed off the smaller screen of a mobile device.
segment.target: The first thing you'll notice is the button is pushed off the smaller screen of a mobile device.

segment.source: Later in this tutorial, you'll learn how to adapt the UI to different screen sizes so your app always looks good.
segment.target: Later in this tutorial, you'll learn how to adapt the UI to different screen sizes so your app always looks good.

segment.source: You might also notice that you can type in the TextBox, but right now, clicking or tapping the Button doesn't do anything.
segment.target: You might also notice that you can type in the TextBox, but right now, clicking or tapping the Button doesn't do anything.

segment.source: In the next steps, you create an event handler for the button's Click event to display a personalized greeting.
segment.target: In the next steps, you create an event handler for the button's Click event to display a personalized greeting.

segment.source: You add the event handler code to your MainPage.xaml.cs file.
segment.target: You add the event handler code to your MainPage.xaml.cs file.

segment.source: Step 4: Create an event handler
segment.target: Step 4: Create an event handler

segment.source: XAML elements can send messages when certain events occur.
segment.target: XAML elements can send messages when certain events occur.

segment.source: These event messages give you the opportunity to take some action in response to the event.
segment.target: These event messages give you the opportunity to take some action in response to the event.

segment.source: You put your code to respond to the event in an event handler method.
segment.target: You put your code to respond to the event in an event handler method.

segment.source: One of the most common events in many apps is a user clicking a Button.
segment.target: One of the most common events in many apps is a user clicking a Button.

segment.source: Let's create an event handler for your button's Click event.
segment.target: Let's create an event handler for your button's Click event.

segment.source: The event handler will get the user's name from the TextBox control and use it to output a greeting to the TextBlock.
segment.target: The event handler will get the user's name from the TextBox control and use it to output a greeting to the TextBlock.

segment.source: Using events that work for touch, mouse, and pen input
segment.target: Using events that work for touch, mouse, and pen input

segment.source: What events should you handle?
segment.target: What events should you handle?

segment.source: Because they can run on a variety of devices, design your Windows Store apps with touch input in mind.
segment.target: Because they can run on a variety of devices, design your Windows Store apps with touch input in mind.

segment.source: Your app must also be able to handle input from a mouse or a stylus.
segment.target: Your app must also be able to handle input from a mouse or a stylus.

segment.source: Fortunately, events such as Click and DoubleTapped are device-independent.
segment.target: Fortunately, events such as Click and DoubleTapped are device-independent.

segment.source: If you're familiar with Microsoft .NET programming, you might have seen separate events for mouse, touch, and stylus input, like MouseMove, TouchMove, and StylusMove.
segment.target: If you're familiar with Microsoft .NET programming, you might have seen separate events for mouse, touch, and stylus input, like MouseMove, TouchMove, and StylusMove.

segment.source: In Windows Store apps, these separate events are replaced with a single PointerMoved event that works equally well for touch, mouse, and stylus input.
segment.target: In Windows Store apps, these separate events are replaced with a single PointerMoved event that works equally well for touch, mouse, and stylus input.

segment.source: To add an event handler
segment.target: To add an event handler

segment.source: In XAML or design view, select the "Say Hello" Button that you added to MainPage.xaml.
segment.target: In XAML or design view, select the "Say Hello" Button that you added to MainPage.xaml.

segment.source: In the Properties Window, click the Events button (Events button).
segment.target: In the Properties Window, click the Events button (Events button).

segment.source: Find the Click event at the top of the event list.
segment.target: Find the Click event at the top of the event list.

segment.source: In the text box for the event, type the name of the function that handles the Click event.
segment.target: In the text box for the event, type the name of the function that handles the Click event.

segment.source: For this example, type "Button\_Click".
segment.target: For this example, type "Button\_Click".

segment.source: Events list in the properties window
segment.target: Events list in the properties window

segment.source: Press Enter.
segment.target: Press Enter.

segment.source: The event handler method is created and opened in the code editor so you can add code to be executed when the event occurs.
segment.target: The event handler method is created and opened in the code editor so you can add code to be executed when the event occurs.

segment.source: In the XAML editor, the XAML for the Button is updated to declare the Click event handler like this.
segment.target: In the XAML editor, the XAML for the Button is updated to declare the Click event handler like this.

segment.source: Add code to the event handler that you created in the code-behind page.
segment.target: Add code to the event handler that you created in the code-behind page.

segment.source: In the event handler, retrieve the user's name from the TextBox control and use it to create a greeting.
segment.target: In the event handler, retrieve the user's name from the TextBox control and use it to create a greeting.

segment.source: Use the TextBlock to display the result.
segment.target: Use the TextBlock to display the result.

segment.source: Debug the app on the local machine.
segment.target: Debug the app on the local machine.

segment.source: When you enter your name in the text box and click the button, the app displays a personalized greeting.
segment.target: When you enter your name in the text box and click the button, the app displays a personalized greeting.

segment.source: Step 5: Adapt the UI to different window sizes
segment.target: Step 5: Adapt the UI to different window sizes

segment.source: Now we'll make the UI adapt to different screen sizes so it looks good on mobile devices.
segment.target: Now we'll make the UI adapt to different screen sizes so it looks good on mobile devices.

segment.source: To do this, you add a VisualStateManager and set properties that are applied for different visual states.
segment.target: To do this, you add a VisualStateManager and set properties that are applied for different visual states.

segment.source: To adjust the UI layout
segment.target: To adjust the UI layout

segment.source: In the XAML editor, add this block of XAML after the opening tag of the root Grid element.
segment.target: In the XAML editor, add this block of XAML after the opening tag of the root Grid element.

segment.source: Debug the app on the local machine.
segment.target: Debug the app on the local machine.

segment.source: Notice that the UI looks the same as before unless the window gets narrower than 641 pixels.
segment.target: Notice that the UI looks the same as before unless the window gets narrower than 641 pixels.

segment.source: Debug the app on the mobile device emulator.
segment.target: Debug the app on the mobile device emulator.

segment.source: Notice that the UI uses the properties you defined in the and appears correctly on the small screen.
segment.target: Notice that the UI uses the properties you defined in the and appears correctly on the small screen.

segment.source: Mobile app screen
segment.target: Mobile app screen

segment.source: If you've used a VisualStateManager in previous versions of XAML, you might notice that the XAML here uses a simplified syntax.
segment.target: If you've used a VisualStateManager in previous versions of XAML, you might notice that the XAML here uses a simplified syntax.

segment.source: The VisualState named has an AdaptiveTrigger with its MinWindowWidth property set to 641.
segment.target: The VisualState named has an AdaptiveTrigger with its MinWindowWidth property set to 641.

segment.source: This means that the state is to be applied only when the window width is not less than the minimum of 641 pixels.
segment.target: This means that the state is to be applied only when the window width is not less than the minimum of 641 pixels.

segment.source: You don't define any Setter objects for this state, so it uses the layout properties you defined in the XAML for the page content.
segment.target: You don't define any Setter objects for this state, so it uses the layout properties you defined in the XAML for the page content.

segment.source: The second VisualState, , has an AdaptiveTrigger with its MinWindowWidth property set to 0.
segment.target: The second VisualState, , has an AdaptiveTrigger with its MinWindowWidth property set to 0.

segment.source: This state is applied when the window width is greater than 0, but less than 641 pixels.
segment.target: This state is applied when the window width is greater than 0, but less than 641 pixels.

segment.source: (At 641 pixels, the is applied.) In this state, you do define some Setter objects to change the layout properties of controls in the UI:
segment.target: (At 641 pixels, the is applied.) In this state, you do define some Setter objects to change the layout properties of controls in the UI:

segment.source: You change the Orientation of the element from Horizontal to Vertical.
segment.target: You change the Orientation of the element from Horizontal to Vertical.

segment.source: You add a top margin of 4 to the element.
segment.target: You add a top margin of 4 to the element.

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: Congratulations, you've created your first app for Windows 10 and the UWP!
segment.target: Congratulations, you've created your first app for Windows 10 and the UWP!
